Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., in grilling Zuckerberg on if Facebook has a monopoly, equated Facebook and Twitter asking, "Is Twitter the same as what you do?"

(Photo: Jack Gruber, USA TODAY)

On Tuesday senators on Capitol Hill grilled Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg about the company's handling of users' privacy in the wake of the Cambridge Analytica scandal that exposed the data of 87 million users.

USA TODAY

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg arrives to testify before a joint hearing of the Senate Committee on the Judiciary and the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation in Washington on April 10, 2018.

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg suited up for Congress

Mississippi Senator Roger Wicker asked Zuckerberg if Facebook tracked users data after they have logged out of the social network.
Sen. Wicker (R-MS): "There have been reports that Facebook can track users' internet browsing history even after that user has logged off of the Facebook platform.

Lawmakers get to ask Zuckerberg more questions Wednesday.

Republican Sen. Orrin Hatch of Utah asked Zuckerberg how Facebook made money.
After a brief pause, Zuckerberg responded with a smile: "Senator, we run ads."
You cannot hold a company accountable if you don't know how its service works.
